name: Google Sheets modules
title: Google Sheets modules

children.text: After connecting to the Google Sheets app, you can use the following modules to build your
in Google Sheets similarly to built-in functions like

(places the sheet in the first place).

children.text: Enter the name of a new spreadsheet.
The locale of the spreadsheet in one of the following formats:
a combination of the ISO language code and country code, such as
The amount of time to wait before volatile functions are recalculated:
Volatile functions are updated upon every change.
Volatile functions are updated upon every change and every minute.
Volatile functions are updated upon every change and hourly.
Select the time zone of the spreadsheet.
Select the default format of all cells in the spreadsheet.
Add sheets to the new spreadsheet.
Create a Spreadsheet from a  Template
Creates a new spreadsheet from a template sheet.

If the spreadsheet contains tags like
Your file must contain at least one tag for this module to work.
Enter a name for the spreadsheet.

Select or map the folder, where the new spreadsheet should be placed.
Copies a sheet to another spreadsheet.

Enter the range of the table headers, e.g.
. If you leave the field empty, Make will suppose that the header is in the first row of the specified range.
The values in the reply will be calculated and formatted according to the cell's formatting. Formatting is based on the spreadsheet's locale, not the requesting user's locale. For example, if
The values will be calculated, but not formatted in the reply. For example, if
The values will not be calculated. The reply will include the formulas. For example, if
and formatted as currency, then A2 will return

Instructs date, time, datetime, and duration fields to be output as doubles in "serial number" format, as popularized by Lotus 1-2-3. The whole number portion of the value (to the left of the decimal) counts the days since December 30th 1899. The fractional portion (to the right of the decimal) counts the time as a fraction of the day. For example, January 1st 1900 at noon would be 2.5. 2 because it's 2 days after December 30th 1899, and .5 because noon is half a day. February 1st 1900 at 3 pm would be 33.625. This correctly treats the year 1900 as not a leap year.
Instructs date, time, datetime, and duration fields to be outputted as strings in their given number format (which is dependent on the spreadsheet's locale).
Gets a list of all sheets in a spreadsheet.

children.text: Select a method to choose the spreadsheet whose rows you want to watch.

Select the Spreadsheet ID whose rows you want to watch.
You can extract the Spreadsheet ID from the spreadsheet URL. For example, the URL is the following:
Enter a sheet name in which you want search rows.
Select whether the spreadsheet contains the header row. If the
option is selected, the module doesn't retrieve the header row as output data, and variables in the output are then called by the headers. If the
option is selected, the module retrieves the first table row, and the output variables are called simply A, B, C, D, etc.
Enter the range of the header row, e.g.,
The values in the reply will be calculated and formatted according to the cell's formatting. Formatting is based on the spreadsheet's locale, not the requesting user's locale. For example, if

Instructs date, time, datetime, and duration fields to be outputted as doubles in "serial number" format, as popularized by Lotus 1-2-3. The whole number portion of the value (to the left of the decimal) counts the days since December 30th, 1899. The fractional portion (to the right of the decimal) counts the time as a fraction of the day. For example, January 1st, 1900 at noon would be 2.5. 2 because it's 2 days after December 30th, 1899, and .5 because noon is half a day. February 1st, 1900 at 3 pm would be 33.625. This correctly treats the year 1900 as not a leap year.
Instructs date, time, datetime, and duration fields to be outputted as strings in their given number format (which depends on the spreadsheet's locale).
Set the maximum number of results thatMakewill work with during one execution cycle.
Appends a new row to the bottom of the table.

data.label: Google Sheets

children.text: Select an option to choose the spreadsheet in which you want to add a row.
Select Google Drive to choose the spreadsheet in which you want to add a row.
Enter the Spreadsheet ID in which you want to add a row.
You can extract the Spreadsheet ID from the spreadsheet URL. For example, the URL is the following:
Enter a sheet name in which you want to add a row.
Select the column range that you want to work with.
Select or map whether the rows should be formatted or not based upon the spreadsheet's existing formatting.
Enter or map the desired cells of the row you want to add.

The values will be parsed as if the user typed them into the UI. Numbers will remain numbers, but strings may be converted to numbers, dates, etc., following the same rules that are applied when entering text into a cell via the Google Sheets UI.
The values the user has entered will not be parsed and will be stored as-is.
Rows are inserted for the new data.
The new data overwrites the existing data in the areas where it is written. (Note: adding data to the end of the sheet will still insert new rows or columns so the data can be written.)

data.label: Google Sheets
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Google Sheets account.

children.text: Select an option to choose the spreadsheet in which you want to update a row.

You can extract the Spreadsheet ID from the spreadsheet URL. For example, the URL is the following:
Select the sheet you want to update a row in.
Enter the number of the row you want to update.
Enter or map the values in the desired cells of the row you want to change (update).

The values will be parsed as if the user typed them into the UI. Numbers will remain numbers, but strings may be converted to numbers, dates, etc., following the same rules that are applied when entering text into a cell via the Google Sheets UI.
The values the user has entered will not be parsed and will be stored as-is.
Appends multiple rows to the bottom of the table.

Instructs date, time, datetime, and duration fields to be output as doubles in "serial number" format, as popularized by Lotus 1-2-3. The whole number portion of the value (to the left of the decimal) counts the days since December 30th 1899. The fractional portion (to the right of the decimal) counts the time as a fraction of the day. For example, January 1st 1900 at noon would be 2.5. 2 because it's 2 days after December 30th 1899, and .5 because noon is half a day. February 1st 1900 at 3 pm would be 33.625. This correctly treats the year 1900 as not a leap year.

Searches rows using Google Charts Query Language. The language is similar to SQL and it is possible to make complex queries. Unfortunately, the response doesn't contain IDs of returned rows. Due to Google Charts, the service is intended for data visualization where the row numbers aren't needed. You can find more information about the query language in the
The maximum number of rows Make should return during onescenarioexecution cycle.

Triggers when a cell is updated.

The module only watches for changes made in the Google Sheets app by the user. Script executions and API requests do not trigger this module. The module does not watch for newly added rows to the sheet.
Changes made via API calls, scripts, or automations will
trigger this module. Only manual edits made by users with the add-on installed will.

children.text: For the list of available endpoints, refer to theGoogle Sheets API Documentation.
Select the HTTP method you want to use:
- to make a partial entry update.
- to retrieve information for an entry.
Enter the desired request headers. You don't have to add authorization headers; we already did that for you.
Enter the body content for your API call.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
